title: Tympanum (architecture)
text:
A tympanum (plural, tympana; from Greek and <a href="wiktionary%3Atympanum%23Latin">Latin words</a> meaning "drum") is the semi-circular or triangular decorative wall surface over an entrance, door or window, which is bounded by a <a href="lintel">lintel</a> and an <a href="arch">arch</a>. It often contains <a href="pedimental%20sculpture">pedimental sculpture</a> or other imagery or ornaments. Many <a href="architecture">architectural</a> styles include this element.
Alternatively, the tympanum may hold an inscription, or in modern times, a clock face.
History.
In <a href="ancient%20Greek%20architecture">ancient Greek</a>, <a href="Roman%20architecture">Roman</a> and <a href="Christian%20architecture">Christian architecture</a>, tympana of religious buildings often contain <a href="pedimental%20sculpture">pedimental sculpture</a> or <a href="mosaic">mosaic</a>s with religious imagery. A tympanum over a doorway is very often the most important, or only, location for <a href="monumental%20sculpture">monumental sculpture</a> on the outside of a building. In classical architecture, and in classicising styles from the <a href="Renaissance%20architecture">Renaissance</a> onwards, major examples are usually triangular; in <a href="Romanesque%20architecture">Romanesque architecture</a>, tympana more often has a semi-circular shape, or that of a thinner slice from the top of a circle, and in <a href="Gothic%20architecture">Gothic architecture</a> they have a more vertical shape, coming to a point at the top. These shapes naturally influence the typical compositions of any sculpture within the tympanum.
The upper portion of a <a href="gable">gable</a> when enclosed with a horizontal <a href="belt%20course">belt course</a>, is also termed a tympanum.
Bands of molding surrounding the tympanum are referred to as the <a href="archivolt">archivolt</a>.
In medieval French architecture the tympanum is often supported by a decorated pillar called a <a href="Trumeau%20%28architecture%29">"trumeau"</a>.
